By an extension of this result such an integral as $\int \frac{dx}{(x+a)^{2}}$ may be evaluated; for let $x+a=t$; then $dx=dt$, and we have: 

\[ \int \frac{dx}{(x+a)^{2}}=\int \frac{dt}{t^{2}}=-\frac{1}{t}+C=-\frac{1}{x+a}+C. \]

Also, 

\[ \int \\left(\frac{a}{a+bx}\right)^{n}dx=\frac{a}{b} \int \frac{du}{(1+u)^{n}},\quad (u=\frac{bx}{a+bx}). \]
The following examples are illustrative of algebraic substitution or transformation.

Our plan in this case is so to arrange the integral that the method of a previous example may be applied.

\[ \int \frac{dx}{\sqrt{2ax-x^{2}}} = \int \frac{dx}{\sqrt{a^{2}-\left(x-a\right)^{2}}}. \]

The change from $dx$ to $d\sqrt{\text{change}}$ being legitimate, since by Example 2, p. 150, the value of the integral is seen to be:

\[ \int \frac{dx}{\sqrt{2ax-x^{2}}}=\frac{1}{2}\cdot\sin^{-1}\left(\frac{x}{a}\right)+C. \]

– To find $\int \frac{dx}{(x^{2}+a^{2})}$. 

In this case the substitution is entirely algebraic.

Let 

$\begin{aligned} & (x^{2}+a^{2}) \text{ is the variable } u. 
\end{aligned}$
